div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: RADICAL SLANDER.
div.p: We hope—though not with much confidence, for the misuhief makers sre tireless io their penitence—that the lost has been heard of the Natal ‘ atrocities” They prove* as might co: fidently have been foretold from the oatseh not to have been atrooities stall. and all tairminded Eugli-hmen will accept without hesitation the rfiidial statement of the Natal Government, which was read in the House of Commons yesterday by the Under¬secretary for the Colouiee. But they will do do more than this. They will reprobate in the strongest manner the disingenuous attitude of the Ministry towards these slanderous attacks 01 the charaoter of their owo kith and kin. Instead of xialom-ly defending the honour of a little Colony ,whioh has been threatened with a terrible danger, the British Government has elected to play the part of a cold, self righteous judge. We deplore - the effeot. which the discussion that followed mnst have, upon all men of British blood ' in South’ Africa, for what the Minister added, of his own initiates, cm only be understood as implying official esnsare upon the coi- dnot of one of tbeufficers ol the Natal forces. For the most sensational act of barbarism asoribed to the troops under the oommand of Colonel Mnokei zie was the foatting off of the head of the arch rebel Bambaata. The sugges tion was that this was done for sheer wan- tODness, as a piece of ferccions savagery, worthy of the dead man himself. We were old that the head was sent round as a'sort of ghastly trophy, to intimidate the other chiefs into sarrguder. Nothing coaid be farther, from the troth. The ofiioial explanation is perfectly simple and honoarable. Bitubasta’s body at the bottom of a deep gorge, twothoasand feet below the oamp, and it was a matter of urgent importance that tbore t-bonld be no doubt as to his fate. Major Platt, of the Army Medical Corps, was sent with a native escort. He fonDd the body badly decomposed,and when the natives refaseid to cury it to camp, the head was ampnta’e I. it was kept under armed- escort in absolate Privacy ; it was only shown to those who- professed to know the chief, and when the identity was verified beyond qnee tion, it was retarnedto the spot where it htd been foand, and baried with the body. Wherein lies the atrooity What is there in this story which need inspire honor or disgust? T'hesnbjeot is an unpleasant one to dwell upon-like everyting connected with a post¬mortem—bnt there is absolutely not a shred of reaion why a British Minister should not have expressed his satisfaction that a fool slander had been so entirely disproved. That, however, is not the way of this Government iu dealing with the British Colonies. Their consistent attitude is to be willing to wound, yet afraid to strike. The Colonial Under S« cretaiy, when asked whether the Government had conveyed any comment on the the fcroat- ment'of Bambata’s body, made the amazing statement that he feated “the British Govern-ment were not in the.best position to act" as oensors. And then he went on to say that under the late Administrationthe Khalifa’s head had been “most shamefally treated and that he thought it obvious that “sneh. an evil precedent wooU be quoted against ns by the Colony in reply to any remonstrance we might think it necessary to make.* When Mr. Arnold Forster, very properly, pressed him to say whether he imputed any disgrace¬ful aot fo Major Platt, the only answer he could obtain was that the Under Secretary for the-Colonies did not think it ’ half so disgrace¬ful as the steps taken in regard to the Mahdi." Frank and open oensore would have been far preferable to this glancing suggestion of con¬demnation, whioh. will be hotly resented in Natal. Moreover,the attack on Lord kitchene was. as gratuitous as it was unwarranted. There is no need dr us to justify what was done in the Sondan after the fall of Omdur- man. On that oooasion, as in Natal, those in command of the troops took the measares they deemed . most efficacious for convincing tbsir beaten and fanatical enemies that further resistance was useless Then, as now, the sensation-mongers wereluiy with their lies. There were Exactly the same charges as to killing the wonnded. ft was boldly eaid that orders had been issued that no quarter should be given. Lord Kitchener was reviled by the tribe of unthinking sentimentalist! at horns, who hardly concealed their regrets that the British oasdal ties were so email in comparison with tbdsd of the Dervishes, and wrote of the Khalifa’s savage tribe men as though they were entitled to the favour and consideration dne to a civilised and hnmaue race.

Massacre there has efen none, though the ghastly mutilations perpetrated upon the few white men who have fallen into the hands pf these Zola rebels would go far to condone any savage reprisals committed in the heat o f action. It is difficult, however, to write with patience of the-atrocity loving public at home, for which these stories are manufactured with unfailing regdlAfity as often as war is afoot No charge is-too outrageoos to find credence,i f only it be brought against their own coontry- men. It is nothing to them if english offi¬cers are stoned and beafeo. to death by the rabble, of an Egyptian village, but their con¬sciences are sorely hart if the morderers are panished. An English police inspector is stabbed through and through with assegais—it is a re¬grettable incident in the eyes of the English Ra¬dical. But when his slayers are tried by court- and fchot the Imperial Gjvernmoat must inter* vene. And if'the rebellion of a horde of blood¬thirsty Zuffir, who would massacre! every man and woman in Natal if once they got the upper hand, is rathlessly crashed under foot by a gallant little band of white men fighting under conditions of great hazard and difficulty, a clamour rises for inquiry, and a Radical 1 Ministry looks on with cold suspicion is' ready with protestations of horror, and grossly attaoks the most distinguished ioidier in the aotfve servioe of the Crown. This Pharisaical attitude of mind is bound to have deplorable results in the Colonies. the slauders pnblisbed here so freely are all sent back over the wires, and read with anger. And the anger is just It is an intolerable thing that in this bard crisis of her fortunes so gallant, so loyal, so public spirited colony as Natal whose sons are fighting in the field, should be slandered n the Press of the Mother Coontry, and find, not friendship, but harsh censorship, in the Brititsh Ministry.
(From the “Daily Telegraph.")

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND GENERAL TRUST.
div.p: THE PROPOSED AMALGAMATION SCHEME REJECTED.

contract Onr company .had during this pe riod held their hands as regards new bosj i oss, and were prejudiced by tho action taken. Considerable fueling was aroused among the shareholders in Egypt, and it is under stood that a member of the Delta London board was specially sent 'to Egypt in connec tion with the fasion of the companies. Ad vances were subseqaently again made to ns, and another preliminary agreement was en tered into on the basis of six. to one. This is the agreement now brought before tho general meeting. The shares to be given to XJS were to* be part of.tjieir authorised re serve of 50,000 shares. / After the second agreement WAS signed the board of this oom pany ascertained that tha Delta Lands Lon don board had in their circular asking con formation of the second agreement also asked their shareholders ta inoreaae their oapital from £250,000 to £'>00,00% or, ip other words, to. double it'Their action appeared to m de¬nsity affect the value of the ' shares they had agreed to give for our assets, and the scatter was, therefore, specially brought to the attention of our shareholders and of the Delta board. In their reply to our rem in strance the Delta board states:—(I) That only power to make sach increase WAS being sought; (9) that such increase was to bo made as and when and if required ; and (3) that the immediate issue of any part of it was so doab fill that the price of issue had not even been consiffere/,' and they farther stater! t|iat if tha occasion arore for issaiog, oar share¬holders were likely to receive cmsiddrable benefit trom a pro rata distribution of new shares. The board of thia’ company are advised by experts well acquainted with Egyptian business thd the mere decision to increase, the capital will be enough to start a selling movement, and that the proposals about the inore>se of capital prej idi oially atfectel the valne of the shares. It is clear that, if their oapital be increased as they propose, the holders ought to be prepared within the specifiel limits to find tin additional oapital wh ch tho Ddta bnrd may from time consider they neet To keep our shares eqni valent to their valae any new issue would have to be at least over £ 1 10s per £ I share. D o our ahareho’ders desire to take up this possible liability which it is proposed should be brought into operation at the d:screti en of the Delta hoard? The reason why your board agreed to the first proposals for amalgamation was beeause th?y%el:eved the De’ta Linds had in past yea's purchased lands on exceptionally favourable terms—lands which had now become for aajle. Their shareholders had waited without dividends, while the shares to be given wero to rank with the original shares. Any increa a of capital certainly alters,the propor¬tion held at the date of the last agreement of the shares then authorised to the existing assets, and it was on thie proportion your board based their consent to the arrangement. Again, is it probable thatnew capital can be emplo yed now by a land company in Egypt, in the face of the prevailing Competition, to the ffame advantage as when the Delta Lands purchased some years ago the Meadi Lands,which ^orm one of their principal assets ? Even if it is probable, do our shareholders desire to increase or double their investments'in Egypt ? The question whether the increase of oapital does or do not materially prejudice the valne of the share! to be given for oar assets is onewhioh yon have to deoide for yourselves and, as our share¬holders include many experienced men «rf basiu'essin Egypt, no doabt an accurate judg¬ment will be given. Although the board are quite prepared, for the reasons before stated, to agree to' amalgamation on fair term", they are in no dernbt as to the success of yonr oompany. The assets are all good, aud are estimated, on a conservative basis, as being worth considerably more than the paid-np oapital, after paying all liabilities. While thes9 matters have been pending between the two companies two instalments of purchase money fjr lands became doe, -on June 30tb and Jaly 1st, and it was provided in the agreement that these should be paid in Egypt by the Delta Lands, they charging interest until it was decided whether the proposed amalgamation was to be approved. If the agreement is confirmed no point arises on this ; but if it is not confirmed the amonUt so disbnrsed will be returned, with the stipulated interest. There are no other liabilities of im¬portance. The half rof the capital of the company which has 'Been called ap has been well employed, and the initial expenses of the oompany were less thin nsaaLfOne of our assets is tho interest of the oompany in the Shorbal Estate, at A’oxaodria. ft is a large bail ling estate, well situated and of ex ceptional and increasing valae, as being almost the only remaining laud available for building purposes within the quadrilateral area which forms Alexandria. The board declined an offer for this proparty, giving a profit of over £30,000 ; bat the company believe that con- si ferfbly largor profits can bo made if this property be olrafnlly realised. The resolutions are now snbmitted to the meeting.
Mr. J«- Robertson seconded t-h j resolutions.
Mr Wrightson asked if the oh’airman coold give the shareholders an 'approximate valua¬tion of theNQomp iny’s assets.
The Chairman said he estimated the value of the assets, after paying all the liabilities, at £130,0r0 net.
Mr. Cadman Jones moved the rejection of the proposals submitted because, in hisopinjor, the Delta Company had not. dealt in good faith.
Mr. Wrightson expreatei himsejf in fivoor of the rejection of the agreement. 4?

Mr. A. P. Mack said he wishe I, in fairness to the Delta Company, to state that when he WAS in Cairo at the end of May he met one of the directors of that company, who did men¬tion that there was a probability of an increase of capital being made.
Mr. Howard asked if the shareholders might Ukalt that the directors as a body did not advise the carrying ont of the amalgamation.

Mr. Wrightson said it seemed to him that the assets showed a share valne of 13s. a share, and if they were to be 'given shares on the basis of 6 to Lthey ought to receive an ex¬change of approximately 78s.

Grookshauk Pasha said he wished to give a little note of warning to the shareholders. Certain things had arisen in Egypt lately wl/ch had con aid drab’y aHered the state of affairs there, and it was nopafc unlikely that they would see the market very low this winter.

The Chairman, replying to Mr,./Howard, said the directors had naturally endeavoured to obtain the opinion of those who were well arquaintod with Egyptian business with regard to the proposed anoalgamation. A member of a firm doing a large business in Cairo, Alex¬andria and London stated that the information from Cairo was that the idea of the Delta C jtupany’s inorease of oapital was not wel¬comed by shareholders, and from Alexandria that the cironlar about the new issae had prodaced a bad impression among shareholders. Taking that view the agreement was one which the directors did not feel justified in pressing on the shareholders.
The resolutions were then pat to the meeting, and lost on a show of ban da by 3 votes to 11

div.head: EGYPTIAN delta LAND AND INVESTMENT cO., LTD.
AMALGAMATION PROPOSALS PROVISIONALLY AGREED TO.
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Com¬pany Ltd., was held on the 19th July at Winchester House, Old Broad-street, E.C., Sir An k’and ^Colvin, K.C.S.I., K.C.M.G.,-C.I.E. (the Chairman of the company), presiding, f The Secretary (Mr. P. J. Horne) having read the notice convening the meeting,

The Chairman said - Yon will doubtle take as read the okonlar sent out by the Board explaining the ohjeots of this meeting. These objects comprise, as yon will have gathered— firstly, the acquisition by this company of the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd , atid, secondly; alterations in the memorandum: and articles of association of our company. Owing to a difficulty which has arisen since the issce to yon-of the notice of this meeting in regard to the fusion of this company with the’Egyptian Land and General Toast, Ltd., it will he cotwe nient to pass first to the resolutions which are not affected thereby—namely, Nos 1, 2/3, 4. 5, 6/7, 8 apd 9. It is the case that resolution No.

V fur the extension of our sphere of operations, is partly due tp the proposed absorption of the Egyptian Land and General Trast, Ltd., be¬muse no suoh restrictions as we are bound by SJ imposed upon that company. But we have every reason to believe that there are good opsoings for basiness in the Soudan and parts of Egypt from which we are now excluded by our memorandum and articles of associa¬tion; and though, if the amalgamation referred to be not oarried through, the primary necessity for the alteration disappears, yet this extension of oar sphere , of operations most, before long, come, and the present would appear to be as good an opportunity as any. of dealing with it. Nos 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 8 are desirable alterations owing to the fact that the Delta Light Railways are no longer shareholders, and in oonsequenoa should no longer have control. In regard to No. 9 we regard it as a safe precaution to raise the minimum number of directors required to form a quorum at a Bjard meeting to two. Directors’ Remuneration.

I now go back to No. 7 on the subject of the remuneration of the directors. The change in the directors’ fees is,a matter which we wished in any case to put before yon. I must remind yoa that this company was originally regarded as likely to be a small affair, an cffihoot of the railways, and accordingly fees and salaries at¬tached to it were fixed proportionately low. Bat it was farther provided that the directors should receive for division amongst themselves 5 per oent of the profits *in any one year after 5 per oent had been paid to th^shareholders.

It is. perhaps as well that oooasion has not yet arisen for such boons to ba claimed. An esti¬mate of the accrued profits may be as safely calculated on. the present market price of oar shares as upon any other basis, and this means that as these profits are realised there will pro¬bably be considerables00*8 for division. What¬ever might be the pecuniary advantages to the Board, they prefer proposing to the share- fhddera that the feei be fixed at what they believe a reasonable and equitable sum, whether as regards the shareh ddera. or directors. 'The fees are at present £IGO to the Chairman and £[() to each direotor, with the prospect of the boons referred to, which it is now proposed that they shoald definitely abandon. In my view, the proposed alterations which I have just enumerated are all desirab’e, whether the amalgamation with the Egyptian Land and General Trm-t, Ltd., is sanctioned oris not. shall be happy to answer any qnestiona in regard to them, so far as it is in my power, And I will proceed to the consideration of the remaining resolutions which depend opon such amalgamation. The general meeting of the Egyptian Land and General Trast. for the con sideratiOn of the fusion of their company with ,ours is fixed for the same time as the one we \re now holding, BO each is at the disadvantage of not knowing the views held or the decision arrived at or likely to be arrived at of the other. The negotiations in connection with the amalgamation commented in E/ypt so far back as February last, when certain diieotors of the two companies met in Egypt 1 need not enter

pon the earlier d.ffi mlties connected with these negotiation0, for they do not bear upon the point now at issue ; but it is neciseary foi roe to explaiu a difficulty created by ■Egyptian Land and General Trust since notices of this meeting were sent to you, andwhich may affect the whole position. To thirwd the secretary will read to-yoa the circular issued by the Egyptian Land and GeneraUrrnst, Lttfi, on the 6th July,' and our reply to(a jetterj/o the secretaries covering such circular dated
the 9 th idem.
The other Company’s Circular.

The Secretary then read the following com mwioation-.—“Egyptian Land and General Trast, Ltd., 68 to 74, Palmerston hoaee, 34, Old Broad street, London, EC., 6th July, 1906. Dear Sir (or Madam),—Since the issue of the 4 last oiroqlar to our shareholders, dated 29th Jaue.recommeudirg the amalgamation with the Egyptian Delta Land and' Investment Company, Ltd., it has been ascertained that the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Ltd..- are asking their shareholders at their general ueeting, to be held op the .9th instant, crease their capital from £250,COO to £590,000 in other words, they propose to double their noteal capital. -The effect of this must b6 depredate the market value of the shares which the Egyptian Delta Land and Invest ment Company, Ltd., under the providonal agreement, w ire Ife give in payment for the assets of^ur company, and in fact, the market value of the shares in both companies has already considerably depreoiatel. Your .di¬rectors ^ava-Aot bien advised when or at whit price it is contemplated to make the new issue; but it is obvious that the apparent imminence so largo an isxue of new shate^mast prevent he value of tho snares hearing the proport’on which existed at the date of the provisional contraot to> the as-eta of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Ltd., already acquired. The basis on which your Board were originally propat ed to support the arrangement has thus been so materially altered that the Board can nrr longer *t ki the respons bility recommending the confirmation 6f the agreement It is imperative th$t the directors should1 know whether the proxioi already for¬warded in response .to their first circular, or to sent in, are to he need for or against the confirmation of the proposed arrangement. Unless, therefore, you ^propose attending the meeting, will yon plAsse signify to ns your ieh in the course oj post £nd forward your proxy if not already Font.— By order of the Board, Mack and Palmer, Secretaries.’’
The Chairman : A copy of the circular was handed to us, and we wrote as follows-—
The Company’s Reply.

The Secretary (reading): * 9tl^July, 1906. Messrs. Mack and Palmer, Fecretaries, Egyptian Laud and General Trust, Ltd, 68 to .74, Pal¬merston House, E C. Dear Sirs,—I received with your assistant secretary’s letter of the 6th instant oopies of circular - of the same date addressed to the proprietors of your company reference to the proposed- increase of this company’s capital. My direotors cannot but regret tha*t they were not afforded an oppor¬tunity of eincidating this subject before the issue by your'oompany of a oiroular which may well cause an erroneous impression of their intentions. Iu this company’s oircnlar of the 29th June it was briefly stated thet it was con¬sidered desirable to increase this company’s capital to £*'00,000, but it was at any rate amalgamation, and the advantages or dis-advantages of any such /arrangement as an inorease of capital would he-shared all alike. Thei^nnmerical strength in shares would he as one to six of our present shareholders, and we might have reasouab’y expeoted them Ao feel safe in accepting the deoision of so large a majority, and of feeling assured that the Jhard of this-company would only exercise the powers conferred upon them in so far aif they belisve that the interests of the company and. therefore, of the shareholders of the Egyptian Land and General Trast, Ltd., would be ad- vancedlhereby.
The Chairman s Proposal. Lv The position being a

The position being as escribed to yoa, my proposal to you is that unless the shareholders of the Egyptian Land and General TrasMje found to have decided upon the amalgamation at their meeting now being hold, and on the terms arranged,such amalgamation be no longer considered by this oompany. If jfou are pleased to accept thia suggestion, I ask you to authorise me to aot in aocirdance therewith in refer¬ence to resolution No. 11, and I will now refer to the preceding resolution No. 10, wbioh the only one remaining. Had it not been for the proposed amalgamation with the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd., we probably shonlduot have asked yoq * so soon to authorise ns to take power to increase our apital, and certainly should not have done so fpr so large an amount. I have explained to yon that no immediate fresh issue of capital

is contemplated, and under tbe^Jiresent condi¬tions of doubt as to whether an amalgamation will or will not take place, I propose to post¬pone this question of an inorease to oor capital until our next meetiog. In the event of an amalgamation the same inorease will be pro¬posed to yon as in the resolntion which* we are considering, but otherwise power will be sought to provide for an addition of £100,000 only, in view of possible, though not probable,
known to Mr. Mack, one of yoar direotors, agencies in oar present sphere of operations,and

that paly power to make snoh inorease was being sought; f2) th* t each increase was to be made as and when and if required ; and (3) that the immediate issue of any part of it was so doubtful that the price of issue had not even been considered. The need for the provision for increasing this company’s capital is created (l)hythefaot that the proposed acquisition of your company’s a9iets will absorb the ba- lame at present available, aud (2) by the proposed extension of its sphere of operation’. The authority now soaght is to provide for this possible want, and it appears to my di-rectors that, if it arises, your shareholders are likely to receivj considerable beuefit from pro rata distribution of new shares, and that as they will only form about one-seventh of the whole they may with confidence accept the decision arrived at bythe larger body—namely, our present shareholders—as to the necessity of making the provision proposed. I may ex plain that whatever inorease be made to this company’s capital yoar shareholders and oars would be equally affeoted in every way. They farther understood from General Hallowes, a direotor of this company, who recently visited Cairo in connection with the fasion of our two companies, that the idea of increasing this company’s capital WAS then mentioned in the presence of Messrs. Mack, Lonsdorfer, Nungo- vich Bey and othe-s. and was received by them-with favour.—Yours faithfully, (Signed} F. J. Horne, Secretary.”

The Charman : I will now explain that the propo al for the acquisition of the Egyptian Land and General Trust necessarily, carried wifh it one ter power to increase this company’s capital. Sach acquisition involved thepaymefit to theEgyptian Land and General Trast of 33,3’4 shares, and 4he advance »to them of £55,000 to meet their liabilities at the 30th June lastion certain lands, and would thus more than absorb the balance of our company’s available capital. A a a consequence, and in view, of payments to become doe for properties acquired, and of the proposed extension of the sphere of our operations, we deemed it advisable totakepower to increaseonrcapital to£500,000. Beyond taking this power. I can unhesitatingly affirm that no programme as to ivsae immediate or otherwise had beeu conridered, and as to any date or price of issue of any of this fresh capita’, 1 can only say that there details have never beeu fixed, and that the circular just read to you ascribes to us intentions which are fir bejond ns. Our intention, as the oiroular dearly expresses it, was simply to take power to issue capital at such futare time as, in oar opinion, might oall for a fresh issue. The power asked for of raising fresh capital and of a pro posal^ to raise fresh- oapital at an early date are absolutely distinct matters. As at present advised we do not propose to make an issne within the next twelve months, and before making any issue we intend to call a meeting of oar shareholders to lay before them the objects for which the issue is proposed, and take their viows as to the cxpendiency of the issue. The biggest issue we have ever made was £100,000, and it would be unreasonable to suppose that we contemplated issuing a quarter of a million, ithir at once or at any one time. 8uoh, how over, seems to have been the opinion created by the oircnlar in question, and on which the di-rectors of that company have withdrawn, as it Feems to os preoipitately, their recommenda¬tion to the Amalgamation of the two companies. Fiom what I have said, it follows that, as and when any fresh istue of our capital was to be made, the shareholders of the Egyptian Land and General Trust would got the benefit of such further issue or issue* equally with our present existing shareholders. The former gentlemen by having acqiffred fehare3 in our company would obtain thb right of subscribing for their proportion, or, bn to other hand, the shares were offered I th the public Ihey would get tin benefityof the proceeds there, The interests of tho /existing shaieholders of our compai y and of those of the Egyptian
Land and General Trast, Ltd., would be
tp avail ourselves of opportunities of bosiness in localities from which we have been hitherto exoladed, but which will now be opened to ns.
Mr. H. P. Singer asked if the Chairman coold give any information as to the reason why the Delta Light Rai’.ways had oeased to be shareholders in the company.

The Chairman replied that as long as the Railway Company were shareho’ders it was difficult for this oompany, with any chanoe of success, to apply to, the Con ft to obtain a modification of the memorandum of assoo:ation necessary to enlarge their sphere of operations. The Railway Company, therefore,' decided, under legal advioe, to dispose of its holding, partly on that account, but also o^the ground that the company bad grown and changed into. much larger oonoern than was originally designed. It was intended originally to parchsse land OD the line of railway in coarse oon- 8traotion and to be oonstraoted, bat the'edm- pany had gone beyond this and the direotors of the railway came to the oonolosion ^hat it was not stfiotly within their powers to be asso-ciated with the Land Company uoder its filter¬ed conditions. They, therefore, decided to with¬ draw from their oonneotion with the oompany. and sold their shares in it. The Railway Com¬pany had.certainly not in any way lost faith the concern, and had exhibited consideiabh^ objection-to onttiog the connection. f
Tho Resolutions.

The Chairman then proposed the following resolutions, which ware duly seconded by Major Li Breton and Major General Hallowes, and unanimously agreed to, namely :—That the memorandum aud artic'.es'of association be varied as follows (1) By striking out from section 3, sub-section (a) of the memoranda m of association the words “in any distriot” and by snbstitnti’pg for the words “in which the railways bilongingto or that may at any time hereaf.er belong to the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd.,* or any extension or branch thereof existing or hereafter constrnoted or proposed to be constrnoted, may serve or be intended to serve” occurring in Jhe same* sub¬section the words “or in thefcadan.” (2) That artiole 75 of the artides of Association of the company be altered by striking oot the words commencing '’and every exercise of the power” down to the end of that article. (3) That article 81 be altejed by striking out the words “or a person to be nominated as hereinafter provided by the Egyptian Delta Light Rail¬ways, Limited.” (4) That article 85 be altered by striking out the wordi “provided that this prohibition tehall not apply to any oontract dealing or transaction with the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd.” (5) That artiole 86 be ajtered by striking oat all words after the words “shall be vaoant” (6) That artiole 87 be altered by.striking ont the words “eave as aforesaid” appearing in the first line of sheb article. (7) That artiole 89. be strode ont and that there be substituted therefor the follow ing article: “The remuneration of the direotors shall' be the sum of £250 per annnm to each of the direotors and £500 per annnm to the Chairman, and such remuneration shall.be deemed to accrue do die in diem. The remune¬ration shall be exclusive of the sums, if any, which under the provisions of these presents the Board may agree to pay to Any managing director or to any director on aooonnt of special services.” (8) That article 90 be altered by striking out the words “provided he be approved by the Board of the Egyptian Delta Light Railwayp, Ltd.” (9) That article 96 be altered by striking ont the words “one direotor” and snbstitutiug therefor the words “two directors.” Capital Resolution Withdrawn.
Tho Chairman stated that resolntion No. 10

“That the capital of the company be increased from £250,000 to £590,00 »”—was withdrawn. He added: Toia will be left over to be dealt with at the uext meeting, which will be field in about four weeks’ tim*. If the amalgama¬tion scheme with the Bgyptian Land and Ge¬neral Trust goes through at that meeting, identical in from the time of the then he increase to £509,000 will be proposed.
He is thus brought to see a great npany of such cases every year, the moat of whom return to their homes to com¬plete their treatment by correspond¬ence. .' ,

If on the other hand, it does not go through, an inorease of an additional £106,000 only will be pot forward. I qext propose to not re¬solution No. 11, with>a small modification inserted. Thia modification is to the effect that the agreement is approved, snbj ot to its being to-day approved at the meeting of the Trast Company. Resolution No. 11 will read as follows"That the memorandam of agree¬ment between the oompany and the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd. now submit¬ted to the meeting, and initialled by the Chair¬man for the purpose of identification, be ap- proved aud authorised to ba entered into, sab- jeot”—aod these are the new words—' to the 8a:d memorandum of agreement being approved this 19th of July by the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd., in general meeting assem¬bled,and”—here end the words inserted—‘ sub- jeot to snoh alterations, as the Board may think fi»; and tint the Board basaukhorised to enter into snoh further or other agreements as they may thick desirable for carrying such memo-randum of agreement into eftect.”
Major Le Breton seconded- the motion, which was carried unanimously.

Mr. Singer : Before we clow the meeting 1 think we should thank our Chairman for the oare he has taken of the company, and also for presiding to-day. We all appreciate the ser¬vices he has rendered to the company in the past, and 1 am snre we oan leave the matter of the amalgamation and the fntnre issue of capi¬tal safely in his hands and those of the other members of the Board. (Applause.)
Mr. W. Baker seconded the motion, wbioh was very condially received.

The Chairman : On behalf of the directors and myself let me thank yon for the expression of confidence yoU have placed in us. Let me also add that I trust the result of oor enterprise will moet all your reasonable wishes. Yon may rely upon it that no efforts shall be spared on our part to show that the confidence yon have reposed in os has not been misplacei. (Ap¬plause.)

div.head: “INVESTMENTS.”
div.p:
“Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are “Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation”; “How to start an Account” ; “The Advantages of ‘Call Options’”; “Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; “How to Invest in Mines”; “American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; “The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; “General Principles for Investors” ; “Rules for Investors in Mines”; “General Principles for Speculators”; “Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; “Stock Exchange Parlance”; “Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and “Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”
“Investments” (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning “Egyptian Gazette.”

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu’au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head:
Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.
